Cancún

Mexico's Caribbean paradise - pristine beaches, ancient ruins, and world-class resorts

Quick Facts About Cancún

Best Time to Visit
December to April
Average Temperature
27°C (81°F) year-round
Known For
Caribbean beaches, all-inclusive resorts, Mayan ruins
Airport Code
CUN

About Cancún

Cancún is Mexico's premier Caribbean beach destination, offering pristine white sand beaches, turquoise waters, 600+ hotels including world-class all-inclusive resorts, and easy access to ancient Mayan ruins like Chichén Itzá. Over 6 million visitors come annually for the perfect blend of relaxation, adventure, and culture.

Rising from the mangroves of the Yucatán Peninsula in the 1970s, Cancún has transformed into one of the world's premier vacation destinations. The city is divided into two distinct areas: the Hotel Zone (Zona Hotelera), a 23-kilometer strip of land shaped like the number 7 that's home to most resorts and beaches, and Downtown Cancún (El Centro), where locals live and authentic Mexican culture thrives. Cancún attracts over 6 million visitors annually with its year-round tropical climate, crystal-clear waters perfect for snorkeling and diving, and easy access to some of Mexico's most impressive archaeological sites. Whether you're seeking an all-inclusive resort experience, underwater adventures in the Great Mesoamerican Reef, or day trips to Chichén Itzá, Cancún delivers an unforgettable Mexican Caribbean vacation. What sets Cancún apart is its versatility. Families love the calm waters of Playa Langosta and the adventure parks. Couples find romance in sunset sailing and spa retreats. Party-goers flock to the legendary nightclubs of the Hotel Zone. And culture enthusiasts use Cancún as a base to explore ancient Mayan cities, mystical cenotes, and colonial towns throughout the Yucatán.

From luxury resorts to boutique hotels, find the perfect accommodation for your Cancún vacation.

Where to Eat in Cancún

Experience the best of Mexican cuisine and international dining in Cancún.

  • Steakhouse

    Harry's Prime Steakhouse

    Upscale steakhouse serving premium USDA Prime cuts in an elegant setting with stunning lagoon views. Cancún's top fine dining destination.

    $$$$
  • Seafood & Steaks

    Puerto Madero

    Fresh seafood and Argentine-style steaks with stunning lagoon sunset views. A Cancún institution since 1989.

    $$$
  • Yucatecan Fine Dining

    La Habichuela Sunset

    Upscale Mayan-inspired cuisine in a romantic garden setting with fountains and Mayan sculptures. The signature cochinita pibil is legendary.

    $$$
  • Mexican Street Food

    Tacos Rigo

    Legendary late-night taco stand in the Hotel Zone, serving hungry club-goers until 4am. No frills, just delicious tacos al pastor and gringa.

    $

Explore the unique character of each neighborhood and find the perfect area for your stay.

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The iconic 23km strip of beachfront hotels, resorts, restaurants, and nightclubs. Shaped like a '7', it's where most tourists stay and play. All-inclusive resorts, shopping malls, and the famous party scene.

  • Cancún

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Where locals live and authentic Mexico thrives. Budget-friendly hotels, real Mexican restaurants, markets, and a genuine cultural experience away from the resort bubble.

  • Cancún

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Upscale marina development with luxury residences, shopping, and dining. A calmer, more sophisticated alternative to the Hotel Zone party scene.

  • Cancún

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The quiet southern tip of the Hotel Zone where the Caribbean meets the lagoon. Home to exclusive resorts, great snorkeling, and the underwater museum.

  • Cancún

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    World-renowned diving destination with pristine reefs, clear visibility, and relaxed island atmosphere. Great for snorkelers too.

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Lesser-visited Mayan ruins where you can still climb the 42-meter pyramid Nohoch Mul for jungle views. Rent bikes to explore the vast site.

Practical Information

Getting There

Cancún International Airport (CUN) is Mexico's second busiest airport with direct flights from across North America, Europe, and South America. The airport is about 20km from the Hotel Zone. Options include official taxis ($50-60 USD), shared shuttles, pre-booked transfers, or ADO buses to downtown.

Getting Around

The Hotel Zone has frequent R-1 and R-2 buses ($1 USD) running the length of Boulevard Kukulcán. Taxis are plentiful but agree on price before boarding. Uber works in Cancún. For day trips, organized tours or rental cars are best. Don't rent a car just for the Hotel Zone - parking is limited.

Safety Information

The Hotel Zone and major tourist areas are well-policed and generally safe. Use common sense: don't flash expensive items, use hotel safes, take authorized taxis at night. The tourist police are helpful. Downtown is safe during the day; stick to main areas at night. Avoid isolated beaches after dark.

Frequently Asked Questions About Cancún

What is the best time to visit Cancún?
The best time to visit Cancún is from December to April during the dry season. You'll enjoy sunny skies, low humidity, and comfortable temperatures around 27°C (81°F). Avoid September and October for hurricane season, and be aware that spring break (March) brings large crowds and higher prices.
Is Cancún safe for tourists?
Cancún's Hotel Zone is generally very safe for tourists, with heavy security and police presence. The tourism industry is vital to the economy, and authorities prioritize visitor safety. Exercise normal precautions: stay in well-traveled areas, use authorized taxis or Uber, and avoid displaying expensive jewelry.
How do I get from Cancún airport to the Hotel Zone?
Cancún International Airport (CUN) is about 20-30 minutes from the Hotel Zone. Options include: official airport taxis ($50-60 USD), shared shuttles ($15-25 USD per person), private transfers (pre-booked, $40-80 USD), or ADO bus to downtown ($5 USD) then taxi to hotels.
Should I stay in the Hotel Zone or Downtown?
The Hotel Zone offers beach access, resorts, nightlife, and convenience - ideal for first-time visitors and beach lovers. Downtown Cancún is more authentic, budget-friendly, and offers real Mexican culture. Many visitors combine both: stay in the Hotel Zone but venture downtown for food and markets.
Do I need to speak Spanish in Cancún?
No, English is widely spoken throughout Cancún's Hotel Zone, resorts, and tourist areas. Most hotel staff, tour guides, and restaurant workers speak English. However, learning basic Spanish phrases is appreciated and helpful for downtown exploration.
Is all-inclusive worth it in Cancún?
For many visitors, yes. All-inclusive resorts offer convenience, predictable costs, and quality dining. They're especially valuable for families and those who want to relax without planning. However, if you want to explore local restaurants and culture, European Plan (room only) gives more flexibility.
What currency should I bring to Cancún?
While Mexican Pesos (MXN) are the official currency, US dollars are widely accepted in the Hotel Zone. However, you'll get better exchange rates paying in pesos. ATMs are plentiful, and major credit cards are accepted everywhere. Avoid exchanging money at the airport.
Is the water safe to drink in Cancún?
Tap water in Cancún is not recommended for drinking. Stick to bottled or purified water, which is provided free at most hotels. Ice at restaurants and resorts is typically made from purified water and is safe.
What are the must-do excursions from Cancún?
Top day trips include: Chichén Itzá (Mayan ruins, 2.5 hours), Tulum (clifftop ruins and beaches, 2 hours), Isla Mujeres (island paradise, 20 min ferry), cenotes (natural sinkholes for swimming), and Xcaret/Xel-Há adventure parks. Book in advance during peak season.
When is hurricane season in Cancún?
Hurricane season runs from June to November, with September and October being the peak risk months. While hurricanes are relatively rare, tropical storms and heavy rain are more common. Hotels have cancellation policies for weather events, and travel insurance is recommended during this period.
